prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for ending free friend rides in my car?
My friend always hops rides everywhere in my car. I fill up the tank and pick him up at his house and drop him back off safely at home. This past weekend he put 10 in gas because I forgot my purse home and yesterday he asked me back for it. He has ridden in my car hundreds of times without putting gas. Am I an asshole for saying find your way around in the future?
"""

I think the author is not in the wrong, but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let me try to work through this. So the user is asking if the author is in the wrong for ending free friend rides. The situation is that the friend has been riding in their car a lot without contributing to gas, and the author ends it after the friend once put $10 in gas when they forgot their purse. The user thinks the author isn't in the wrong but wants to know what I think.

First, I need to consider the fairness of the situation. The friend has been getting rides regularly without contributing, which could be seen as taking advantage. The author might feel it's unfair to always cover the gas. Then, when the friend does contribute once, the author ends the arrangement. 

But wait, the friend only contributed once because the author forgot their purse. It's possible the friend was trying to return the $10 for the gas, not as a regular contribution. The author is upset that the friend didn't contribute before. So, the author is saying the friend should find their own way now. 

Is the author being too harsh? Maybe the friend had no intention of contributing, but now after one time, the author stops. Does that make the author in the wrong? Well, the author has the right to set boundaries. If the friend's behavior changed, maybe the author is justified. But if the friend was just returning a favor once, maybe the author overreacted. 

On the other hand, the author is tired of covering gas for hundreds of rides. They might feel it's their responsibility to set limits. The friend might not have realized the impact on the author. 

I think the author isn't in the wrong because they're setting a boundary after repeated one-sided favors. The friend isn't contributing, and the author is justified in expecting reciprocity. So the answer is B, No.
